author: bridge-bot
content:
<MMJahanara> The general direction of the EIP makes perfect sense to me! Is it actively being considered for L1?

The only part that seems a bit uncertain to me is the 10x factor. Why not 5x or 20x? Especially since the cost would vary for each proof system. A multi-dimensional fee market, which charges a proof fee per opcode proportional to the number of constraints it costs (or rows in the constraint table), would be more accommodating of different proof systems. (re @vb271828: Have these been discussions about adopting https://eips.ethereum.org/EIPS/eip-7667 on L2s?)

author: bridge-bot
content:
<eliastzr> It’d be interesting to transform this EIP into an RIP and ship it to ZK-Rollups first? (re @MMJahanara: The general direction of the EIP makes perfect sense to me! Is it actively being considered for L1?

The only part that seems a bit uncertain to me is the 10x factor. Why not 5x or 20x? Especially since the cost would vary for each proof system. A multi-dimensional fee market, which charges a proof fee per opcode proportional to the number of constraints it costs (or rows in the constraint table), would be more accommodating of different proof systems.)

author: bridge-bot
content: <mratsim> type 2~3~4 zk rollups already reprice hash functions, and type 1 cannot reprice them (re @eliastzr: It’d be interesting to transform this EIP into an RIP and ship it to ZK-Rollups first?)

author: bridge-bot
content:
<eliastzr> might as well make it more standard 
scroll just censors keccak after a certain threshold per block,
kakarot missprices keccak (same pricing as l1) (re @mratsim: type 2~3~4 zk rollups already reprice hash functions, and type 1 cannot reprice them)

author: bridge-bot
content: <vb271828> yeah this is why I care about this, it feels like zkrollups are all using these incredibly ugly and harmful tricks to get around what is ultimately just an opcode mispricing problem

author: bridge-bot
content:
<vb271828> So I started asking around for some concrete numbers about a month ago, this is what I have so far:

https://notes.ethereum.org/@vbuterin/evm_vs_keccak_benchmarks (re @MMJahanara: The general direction of the EIP makes perfect sense to me! Is it actively being considered for L1?

The only part that seems a bit uncertain to me is the 10x factor. Why not 5x or 20x? Especially since the cost would vary for each proof system. A multi-dimensional fee market, which charges a proof fee per opcode proportional to the number of constraints it costs (or rows in the constraint table), would be more accommodating of different proof systems.)

author: bridge-bot
content: <vb271828> Honestly, the 10x was a bit of a placeholder; it's the most by which you can bump up the price without increasing the cost of some critical stuff (eg. merkle branch verifications) by more than 2x

author: bridge-bot
content:
<vb271828> but this is very rough, it could be improved a lot if we really took the benchmarking effort seriously (re @vb271828: So I started asking around for some concrete numbers about a month ago, this is what I have so far:

https://notes.ethereum.org/@vbuterin/evm_vs_keccak_benchmarks)

author: bridge-bot
content:
<RenoRen79> Very interesting, we really need those benchmarks. But i don't understand the ratios computed

Linea: 30us per gas = 30K gas/sec
kakarot 20 min for 4M = 3K gas/sec, why the displayed ratio is greater for linea (smaller=better).

A ratio on proving is given here at 12m30s
https://youtu.be/_eha0QqAbIA?si=rJ4iUBdi06CaNKEV (https://youtu.be/_eha0QqAbIA?si=rJ4iUBdi06CaNKEV) (re @vb271828: So I started asking around for some concrete numbers about a month ago, this is what I have so far:

https://notes.ethereum.org/@vbuterin/evm_vs_keccak_benchmarks)

author: bridge-bot
content: <RenoRen79> The speaker also states that risc0 last results is 25K, thus 20% better than S2

author: bridge-bot
content: <RenoRen79> It would be really helpfull for crosschain developpers to have a reference benchmarks (maybe initiated by the EF as impartial).

author: bridge-bot
content: <vb271828> the ratios are (N gas of keccak) / (N avg gas)

author: bridge-bot
content: <vb271828> the point is to compare keccak vs avg gas within each zkevm

author: bridge-bot
content: <vb271828> without even trying to compare zkevms against each other

author: bridge-bot
content:
<MauroT> I think we should be able to measure the numbers with a Devnet of Era and SP1 Reth. I'll see how to run everything, try to bench, and come back. If non EVMs are also interested we could also check with that ones. (re @vb271828: So I started asking around for some concrete numbers about a month ago, this is what I have so far:

https://notes.ethereum.org/@vbuterin/evm_vs_keccak_benchmarks)

author: bridge-bot
content: <eliastzr> As soon as Stone and later Stwo is easily runnable in a docker on Kakarot I’d be happy to contribute to the open benchmark effort (re @MauroT: I think we should be able to measure the numbers with a Devnet of Era and SP1 Reth. I'll see how to run everything, try to bench, and come back. If non EVMs are also interested we could also check with that ones.)

author: bridge-bot
content: <tyneslol> If L1 adopted it we would certainly adopt it in the OP Stack but premature to think about it otherwise. We are working towards zk proving our fault proof but realistically it will be awhile (re @vb271828: Have these been discussions about adopting https://eips.ethereum.org/EIPS/eip-7667 on L2s?)

author: bridge-bot
content: <gakonst> How does OP Stack in general think of not-L1 adopted EIPs, for example EOF? (re @tyneslol: If L1 adopted it we would certainly adopt it in the OP Stack but premature to think about it otherwise. We are working towards zk proving our fault proof but realistically it will be awhile)
